 Bishop: Christians don't go to heaven
 
 
 N.T. "Tom" Wright, the fourth most senior cleric in the Church of England who has been praised for his staunch defense of the literal resurrection of Jesus Christ, has published a new book in which he says people do not ascend to God's dwelling place. Instead, deceased believers are in a sleep-like state until God comes back to Earth.
 
 "Never at any point do the Gospels or Paul say Jesus has been raised, therefore we are we are all going to heaven," Wright told Time Magazine. "I've often heard people say, 'I'm going to heaven soon, and I won't need this stupid body there, thank goodness.' That's a very damaging distortion, all the more so for being unintentional."
 
 When asked to explain why he rejects that typical sentiment, he said, "There are several important respects in which it's unsupported by the New Testament. First, the timing. In the Bible we are told that you die, and enter an intermediate state. [The Apostle] Paul is very clear that Jesus Christ has been raised from the dead already, but that nobody else has yet. Secondly, our physical state. The New Testament says that when Christ does return, the dead will experience a whole new life: not just our soul, but our bodies. And finally, the location. At no point do the resurrection narratives in the four Gospels say, 'Jesus has been raised, therefore we are all going to heaven.' It says that Christ is coming here, to join together the heavens and the Earth in an act of new creation."
 
 In the Gospel of John, Jesus himself is quoted as saying, "And no man hath ascended up to heaven, but he that came down from heaven, even the Son of man which is in heaven." (John 3:13).....
 
 .....many people have been confused about what happens at death by Jesus' statement to a thief who was being executed next to him.
 
 He explained: "There is Luke 23, where Jesus says to the good thief on the cross, 'Today you will be with me in paradise.' But in Luke, we know first of all that Christ himself will not be resurrected for three days, so 'paradise' cannot be a resurrection. It has to be an intermediate state. And chapters 4 and 5 of Revelation, where there is a vision of worship in heaven that people imagine describes our worship at the end of time. In fact it's describing the worship that's going on right now. If you read the book through, you see that at the end we don't have a description of heaven, but, as I said, of the new heavens and the new Earth joined together."
 
 Wright says much of "traditional Christianity" has been influenced by pagan philosophies.
 
 "Two obvious ones are Dante's great poetry, which sets up a heaven, purgatory and hell immediately after death, and Michelangelo's 'Last Judgment' in the Sistine chapel, which portrays heaven and hell as equal and opposite last destinations. Both had enormous influence on Western culture, so much so that many Christians think that is Christianity," he said.

Why do atheists/agnostics/skeptics always feel that the burden of proof should be placed on the believers? 
 
 ( As an aside, I am proud to be a religious nutjob, but I'm the kind that doesn't deal in absolutes, or condemn anybody for not being a religious nutjob like me. If I hadn't had the experiences I did, I wouldn't believe either. Yes, I think it's funny when some of us nutjobs try to prove something by quoting the bible to people that don't believe in the bible.)
 
 So you are absolutely right. There is no empirical way for us to prove life after death. However, if we are right, then God did that on purpose. This life is a test to see of we can live on faith. 
 
 *HOWEVER*
 
 I submit that there is no empirical evidence to convince me that there is no life after death. Pesky thing, ain't it? 
 
 
Isn't it a little arrogant to think you know exactly what happens after death?

 
 SO: It must be just as arrogant to say that nothing happens after death. That's thinking you know what happens after death. 
 
 THEREFORE: Since the proof is non-existent on either side, any guess is technically just as valid as the next. The more I study molecular and quantum physics, the more I am convinced that this is a universe of infinite possibility. In such a universe, believing that we will end up with a Supreme Being in a state of eternal happiness depending on how we lived our life is just as likely that we will end up disappearing into oblivion as our body stops functioning. It's also just as likely that we will end up watching eternal re-reruns of "I Love Lucy" from some sort of giant cosmic bubble bath. I'm convinced that it's the one, but I'm fine to agree to disagree.
 
 Speaking personally, I know exactly why I believe I know. I feel that each of us has the ability to communicate with God. He speaks to the heart. After having felt it, I feel that it is very apparent that He exists, and that all of reality as we know it is His handiwork. To me it is clearer than the sun shining in the sky. However, this is a personal thing, and just as I am not the only one to feel the way I do, you are not alone in feeling that this is complete blarney. It is completely understandable to be perplexed at the conviction of us religious nutjobs and our "magical spider sense". I am sure that people will begin to rip this to shreds, and please feel free to; but as you tear it apart, I ask you to be respectful. This is very dear to me.
 
 BOTTOM LINE: If you don't feel like trying out the believing thing, or have tried it, and decided against it; that's fine. In that case, the only way to find out if there is life after death is to get there. (Or wait until science finds something about it, which I think is impossible,) If I am wrong, I won't be around to regret believing in an afterlife. If we are right, then come find me when you get there, and I'll explain what's going on. ;) Unless it's the Cosmic Bubble Bath. Then you're on your own. 
 
 (Please don't take me seriously on that last comment. Just making jokes. If they aren't funny, just ignore them. I know my jokes are usually lame. My friends tells me that all the time.)

 Here's what I just posted in response to an atheist on another thread. I know that you are all eager to rip it to shreds and laugh at it, but I'll post it anyhow:
 
 
Quote:
 
 Quote: I ask why he would not speak to me if he had something to say?
 It is the fact that there is no plausible answer to that question that leads me to the conclusion that he does not (if he exists in the sense being spoken of) communicate to humans.
 There is indeed an answer. And I can almost promise that you have heard it, and just don't like it, therefore you consider it not an answer. Your conclusion is based on a given understanding of the nature of God. We understand the nature and purposes of God differently. If what we believe (and feel that we know,) is true, then God exists, and that purpose of life is a test to see if we can live by faith. This means God will not prove Himself to exist. A belief means that we must first open our minds to the possibility of its reality. Then we experiment with the idea. I submit this as an excellent (and fairly short,) discourse on the subject of experimentation of faith with an open mind: Reference Search: Alma 32:26-40 
 The language used is fairly archaic, but you seem to me intellectual enough that it shouldn't be a problem.
 One must also ask oneself how God may respond. If you are looking for big, shining messages written in the sky, then good luck. This life is based on faith, so it will be something that is possible to disbelieve. A feeling. A strong feeling, but a feeling. If you go with the feeling, you get a stronger reassurance, then stronger still, and so on. 
 
 I know, it is very easy to protest, and explain this all away with psychological principles of reinforcement. That's the point. It's all based on faith. If what we believe is true, then if you want to believe it, God reinforces it. If you don't want to, then God does not force you to. 
 
 The bottom line is that faith is a choice. 
 
 Quote:
 What does "allowed God to speak to you" consist of?
 According to me, it would be being willing to change your life, even in the most difficult of ways, based on the answer you get. Asking God if He exists, and sincerely, deeply wanting to know. A casual approach rarely gives results. God is not interested in casual followers. You have to work really hard to open the account before He will make a deposit. It's called a "leap of faith." Sincerely giving yourself the possibility that He exists. Fully opening one's mind AND one's heart to the idea.
 
 Quote:
 Why is it not the healthy conscious state of a human being that God would wish to speak to, he created us right?
 Perhaps a Buddhist meditation belt or some South American trance drugs could help?
 Lol, I wouldn't recommend the drugs... Hey, if you like the belt, why not? But srsly, He does speak to the healthy conscious state, when you put yourself into one by realizing how very little we know. We like to think we're pretty smart, but God will not force faith on people who think they know He doesn't exist. He won't try to pour anything into a cup that you have already filled. You must be willing to relearn what you think you know, and admit to yourself that you might be mistaken. 
 
 Quote:
 Trying hard enough consists of telling yourself something so many times that you form the illusion its happening.
 Yup. But what makes you say it's an illusion? Like I said, if we are right, then God will always leave you some other way to explain it; an out that allows you to disbelieve. It seems to me that He gives ten reasons to believe and one not to. It's up to you which way you go.
 
 Yes, it's easy to say, "Keep telling yourself that fairy tale if it makes you feel better." That's funny though, because that's exactly how we believers feel about your position. I think you will agree when I say that it all boils down to faith, and how badly you want to believe in God. (We just have different opinions about what exactly that means. I say it means you must allow God to convince you. You say it means that you must allow you to convince yourself.)
 
 I have no empirical evidence that God exists. God planned it that way. Yet I submit that you have no empirical evidence that He doesn't. When I say that, I mean empirical. Tangible. I am not a sophist. Mere talk will not convince me, just as it will not convince you. All I can really say is that I believe in Him. He has taught me to love all people for the spark of divinity that we all carry as children of God. He has taught me that every one is my brother or sister. He has taught me not to judge, because I am so very imperfect that I would not want to be judged. I don't pretend to be perfect, or remotely close. I am not a very good example of a follower of Christ. I make mistakes like anybody else. I just believe that God's and Christ's teachings make bad men good and good men better. I'm somewhere on the road after "bad man," and trying to make it to "good man." Where I am now, who knows. I just know that I make fewer mistakes than I used to. To you, this is probably all just emotional, deluded babble. Sorry if it comes across that way.
 
 Even if somebody were able to prove to me that it was all untrue, (which, because of the metaphysical nature of the topic is just as impossible as proving it true,) I would still follow it, because living the way I believe now makes me happier, more at peace than I was before. I believe it. Yet I cannot blame you for not believing it. Religion is, and always will be, a personal choice.

 
 That's the end of my emotional rambling for the night. Have fun with it! I've given you plenty to tear apart, there. Please at least try to be respectful though. This is really close to my heart.
 
 Bottom line: Believe if you want, don't if you don't. Just understand the that the "evidence" which you seem to think is on your side is just as subjective as the "evidence" we seem to think is on ours. Actual evidence is impossible.

 Robert Lanza, M.D.: Do You Only Live Once? Experiments Suggest Life Not One-Time Deal
 
We think we die and rot into the ground, and thus must squeeze everything in before it's too late. If life-yours, mine-is a just a one-time deal, then we're as likely to be screwed as pampered. But experiments suggest this view of the world may be wrong.
 
 The results of quantum physics confirm that observations can't be predicted absolutely. Instead, there's a range of possible observations each with a different probability. One mainstream explanation, the "many-worlds" interpretation, states that there are an infinite number of universes (the "multiverse"). Everything that can possibly happen occurs in some universe. The old mechanical-"we're just a bunch of atoms"-view of life loses its grip in these scenarios. 
 
 Biocentrism extends this idea, suggesting that life is a flowering and adventure that transcends our ordinary linear way of thinking. Although our individual bodies are destined to self-destruct, the "me'' feeling is just energy operating in the brain. But this energy doesn't go away at death. One of the surest principles of science is that energy never dies; it can neither be created nor destroyed. When we die, we do so not in the random billiard ball matrix but in the inescapable life matrix. Life has a non-linear dimensionality-it's like a perennial flower that returns to bloom in the multiverse. 
 
 A series of landmark experiments show that measurements an observer makes can influence events that have already happened in the past. One experiment (Science 315, 966, 2007) confirmed that flipping a switch could retroactively change a result that had happened before the switch was flipped. Regardless of the choice you, the observer, make, it'll be you who will experience the outcomes-the universes-that will result...
 
 "Whenever anything in nature seems to us ridiculous, absurd or evil," said Spinoza "it is because we have but a partial knowledge of things." 
 
 Life has a power that transcends any individual history or universe...

 Well, that sounds like a bunch of pseudoscience nonsense. I do know that the 'effects before the flip switch' , as he describes it, violates the principle of causality, so I rather suspect he doesn't understand the experiment.
 
 If someone wants to make a claim about what quantum mechanics implies , I will be double skeptical if the claim is way out, and they are not a phd in physics. I will only be highly skeptical if they have a phd in physics.
